intro: Silene sanctae-therasiae, commonly known as the Holy Theresa's catchfly, is a rare and endangered species native to the Mediterranean region. It is a flowering plant belonging to the Caryophyllaceae family, characterized by its delicate, pinkish-purple flowers and hairy stems. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in sunny, well-drained environments. Its small, capsule-like fruits contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, conservation efforts are crucial for its survival.
